This tutorial sets up a mcp-server-webcrawl search connection from InterroBot web crawler and analyzer, to Claude Desktop. mcp-server-webcrawl handles search and retrieval of the archive, allowing Claude to filter and analyze web content archived with SiteOne.

What you'll learn:
- Installing mcp-server-webcrawl via pip
- Configuring Cloud desktop for your MCP server
- Using InterroBot to create local web archives
- Enabling your LLM to search and retrieve content
- Testing your setup with example.com and pragmar.com

This open-source tool is for developers, SEOs, web content administrators--anyone looking to leverage web content, work with archived web content, or create specialized knowledge bases for their LLMs.

1
00:00:09,280 --> 00:00:12,560
Hey, this is Ben from InterroBot. In my other videos

2
00:00:12,561 --> 00:00:15,840
I've gone over crawler and MCP configuration,

3
00:00:15,841 --> 00:00:18,120
so I thought it was time to go a little bit deeper

4
00:00:18,121 --> 00:00:20,400
into the practical aspects of the server.

5
00:00:22,160 --> 00:00:25,160
mcp-server-webcrawl is, at a fundamental level,

6
00:00:25,161 --> 00:00:28,160
a search interface.

7
00:00:28,161 --> 00:00:30,360
You use it to filter pages and return content

8
00:00:30,361 --> 00:00:32,560
for review or additional processing.

9
00:00:34,480 --> 00:00:37,760
Where Google is an all-of-web search interface

10
00:00:37,761 --> 00:00:41,040
designed for humans, mcp-server-webcrawl is a website

11
00:00:41,041 --> 00:00:44,640
level interface designed for AI language models.

12
00:00:44,641 --> 00:00:48,240
You can direct search as much as you want.

13
00:00:48,241 --> 00:00:51,920
The LLM is capable of searching and processing

14
00:00:51,921 --> 00:00:55,600
autonomously. So you can, for example, give it a goal,

15
00:00:56,880 --> 00:00:58,000
and just let it have at it.

16
00:01:02,320 --> 00:01:04,960
In fact, you can use the server as a custom site search,

17
00:01:04,961 --> 00:01:07,600
and it's a good introduction to the server

18
00:01:07,601 --> 00:01:11,200
to see it operate with results in full view.

19
00:01:11,201 --> 00:01:14,800
So say I've got this NASA SOHO site crawled,

20
00:01:14,801 --> 00:01:18,920
and I'm looking for "dopplergram"

21
00:01:18,921 --> 00:01:23,040
And if I get a noisy results at back,

22
00:01:24,320 --> 00:01:26,880
and I don't want these Joint Observing Plan (JOP) pages

23
00:01:26,881 --> 00:01:29,440
with a little bit of Boolean search I can

24
00:01:29,441 --> 00:01:32,360
fill through them out. And I can even tell Claude,

25
00:01:32,361 --> 00:01:35,280
look, I don't know the actual Boolean,

26
00:01:35,281 --> 00:01:39,200
but just get as close as you can to this.

27
00:01:39,201 --> 00:01:43,120
And I haven't had bad results doing that.

28
00:01:43,121 --> 00:01:46,320
Like, Claude is actually pretty good at Boolean queries.

29
00:01:46,321 --> 00:01:49,520
In this case, I'm searching "dopplergram"

30
00:01:49,521 --> 00:01:52,760
Cram, but I mean, you might be searching a product skew,

31
00:01:52,761 --> 00:01:56,000
or someone's name, or a JavaScript

32
00:01:56,001 --> 00:01:59,200
preference, because it's not just all about the HTML pages.

33
00:01:59,201 --> 00:02:02,400
There's a world of CSS,

34
00:02:02,401 --> 00:02:05,440
JavaScript, you name it as just as valuable

35
00:02:05,441 --> 00:02:08,480
to some of you out there as the HTML itself.

36
00:02:08,481 --> 00:02:12,000
And of course, you see these search results as snippets,

37
00:02:12,001 --> 00:02:15,520
but snippets is just one perspective on the

38
00:02:15,521 --> 00:02:19,800
content. You can alternatively retrieve results

39
00:02:19,801 --> 00:02:24,080
as raw HTTP content, or page mark down,

40
00:02:25,120 --> 00:02:29,000
or the latest features you can even zero in on XPath.

41
00:02:29,001 --> 00:02:32,880
So you can collect just what you need,

42
00:02:32,881 --> 00:02:37,000
and really just manage that token load.

43
00:02:37,001 --> 00:02:41,120
Often you don't need the HTTP body at all.

44
00:02:42,400 --> 00:02:45,160
mcp-server-webcrawl encourages efficient token usage.

45
00:02:45,161 --> 00:02:47,920
You can control the context window

46
00:02:48,080 --> 00:02:50,080
by allowing the query results to be as light

47
00:02:50,081 --> 00:02:52,080
or as dense as you need.

48
00:02:52,081 --> 00:03:00,320
I can find the largest images, CSS, or JavaScript.

49
00:03:09,920 --> 00:03:13,680
Likewise, I could target 404 errors using HTTP status,

50
00:03:13,681 --> 00:03:17,440
or a particular character set using headers.

51
00:03:17,441 --> 00:03:20,760
Or mix and match field level and full text search.

52
00:03:20,761 --> 00:03:24,080
The Boolean search foundation of mcp-server-webcrawl

53
00:03:24,081 --> 00:03:27,120
is solid. So you can search crawls with high precision,

54
00:03:27,121 --> 00:03:30,160
and you've seen the snippets

55
00:03:30,161 --> 00:03:32,760
present in clear view. But in most cases,

56
00:03:32,761 --> 00:03:35,360
search results are processed in the background.

57
00:03:36,560 --> 00:03:39,240
You might expand the MCP interaction to verify

58
00:03:39,241 --> 00:03:41,920
a search query or the results return,

59
00:03:41,921 --> 00:03:45,320
but if the AI is searching predictably and it's giving you

60
00:03:45,321 --> 00:03:48,720
what you need, this isn't necessary.

61
00:03:48,721 --> 00:04:01,460
So the server provides both search and content retrieval,

62
00:04:01,461 --> 00:04:11,200
along with these content extras to

63
00:04:11,201 --> 00:04:15,240
give a lot of degrees of freedom to get what you're after.

64
00:04:15,241 --> 00:04:19,280
You can embed these crawl queries in complex

65
00:04:19,281 --> 00:04:21,640
prompts. You can write these yourself,

66
00:04:21,641 --> 00:04:24,000
or if you just want to get your feet wet,

67
00:04:24,001 --> 00:04:27,560
there are examples that I wrote in the GitHub repo.

68
00:04:27,561 --> 00:04:31,120
So like the site selection, all the interaction

69
00:04:31,121 --> 00:04:35,200
becomes guided. It's an efficient way to script a test

70
00:04:35,201 --> 00:04:39,280
or report, because the queries in the

71
00:04:39,281 --> 00:04:44,360
logic can be expressed in broad strokes

72
00:04:44,361 --> 00:04:49,440
using plain language. If you haven't checked these prompts

73
00:04:49,441 --> 00:04:53,160
out, there worth a look. I develop InterroBot crawler.

74
00:04:53,161 --> 00:04:56,880
I wrote a plug-in system in a series of plugins.

75
00:04:56,881 --> 00:05:00,960
Don't get me wrong. The InterroBot core plugins are more

76
00:05:00,961 --> 00:05:05,040
advanced, more deterministic, and the UI is a

77
00:05:05,041 --> 00:05:09,120
lot more polished than these prompts, but they took

78
00:05:09,121 --> 00:05:13,200
so much longer to write. Like two, three months

79
00:05:13,201 --> 00:05:16,760
for the InterroBot plugins compared to like a couple

80
00:05:16,761 --> 00:05:20,320
of days for the prompts. And the prompts get you

81
00:05:20,321 --> 00:05:25,720
80% there. The LLM can be glitchy on occasion,

82
00:05:25,721 --> 00:05:31,120
and presentation is chat. It's nothing

83
00:05:31,121 --> 00:05:34,000
not right home about, but the fact that it can do

84
00:05:34,001 --> 00:05:36,800
a reasonable job of reviewing any number of

85
00:05:36,801 --> 00:05:42,860
website issue classes is notable.

86
00:05:42,861 --> 00:05:49,920
What is that last 20% worth? Does it outweigh the

87
00:05:49,921 --> 00:05:53,640
convenience of a direct API? I'm still trying to figure

88
00:05:53,641 --> 00:05:57,360
that out. But let me know what you think in the

89
00:05:57,361 --> 00:06:01,720
comments. mcp-server-webcrawl is a search tool

90
00:06:01,721 --> 00:06:06,080
for web data integrates with your LLM.

91
00:06:06,081 --> 00:06:18,560
It's all I have for you today. Stay tuned.
